## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**AI Assistant:**
Hey there! I'm here to assist you in understanding Verus. What's on your mind today?

**User:**
I've been reading about Verus and I came across the term "Basket currency." What is a "Basket currency" in Verus?

**AI Assistant:**
A "Basket currency" is a type of currency in Verus that has reserves and can be converted to and from those reserves. It can have one currency as its reserve or multiple currencies, up to a maximum of 10. This type of currency can be launched in a centralized or decentralized manner. Would you like to know more about how basket currencies work or is there something else on your mind?

**User:**
That's helpful, thanks. I was also looking at the Verus currency definition and saw an "options" parameter. What does that do?

**AI Assistant:**
The "options" parameter in Verus currency definition is used to specify various properties of the currency. It is a bitfield, which means that individual options can be combined by adding their values. For example, "options":33 would launch a basket currency, which is a combination of options 1 and 32. Do you have any specific questions about the options available or how to use them?

**User:**
I saw an option 2048 mentioned. What does that do in Verus currency definition?

**AI Assistant:**
Option 2048 in Verus currency definition creates a single satoshi (0.00000001) NFT token that has tokenized control of the root VerusID. This means that the single satoshi token can be sent to other addresses, and the recipient will gain control of the root VerusID. Would you like to know more about how this works or is there something else you're curious about?

**User:**
Another parameter I saw was "proofprotocol." What is the purpose of that in Verus currency definition?

**AI Assistant:**
The "proofprotocol" parameter in Verus currency definition defines whether the currency is centralized or decentralized. It can take three values: 1 (default, decentralized), 2 (centralized), or 3 (for Ethereum ERC-20 mapped tokens). This parameter is important for determining how the currency will be managed and secured. Do you have any further questions about proof protocols or currency definitions in Verus?
What is a "Basket currency" in Verus?

A "Basket currency" is a type of currency in Verus that has reserves and can be converted to and from those reserves. It can have one currency as its reserve or multiple currencies, up to a maximum of 10. This type of currency can be launched in a centralized or decentralized manner.

| Options # | Details | | -: |:-----| | 1 | The currency has reserves, and can be converted to and from the reserves (option 32 needs to be added). Can have one currency as its reserves, or multiple with up to 10 currencies. This is a “Basket currency” — a currency with a basket of reserves. Such a currency can be launched centralized or decentralized. | | 2 | Only the controlling VerusID (the namespace of the currency, the rootID) can create subIDs. | | 8 | Referrals and discounts are enabled for subID creation. | | 16 | Referrals are required for subID creation. | | 32 | The currency is a simple token currency without any reserves. Such a currency can be launched centralized or decentralized. This option is also used for [Ethereum ERC-20 mapped tokens](/currencies/mapping-1:1-eth). | | 2048 | A single satoshi (0.00000001) NFT token is created & has tokenized control of the root VerusID. Which means you can send the single satoshi token to other addresses and then they have control of the root VerusID. |Let’s give some examples of combined options: - ``"options":33`` — this launches a basket currency. It is options 1 + 32 combined. - ``"options":2080`` — this launches a single satoshi token that has control of the root VerusID. It is options 32 + 2048 combined. - ``"options":35`` — this launches a basket currency, and only the rootID can create subIDs. It is options 1 + 2 + 32 combined.## Defining parameters Next up are the parameters. Choose the parameters wisely to launch a currency that suits any need. Not all parameters are needed or combinable. There are many to go through, so let’s start.### **"proofprotocol"** This parameter defines, among others, if the currency is centralized or decentralized. You can choose 1,2 or 3.``1`` is default, which launches a decentralized currency (no need to include this parameter when defining such a currency). When subIDs are created with this option, the registration fees are burned.``2`` is for a centralized currency. If it’s a basket currency the rootID can mint and burn supply while automatically lowering and raising the reserve ratio (also anyone can burn supply without lowering the reserve ratio). Or when it’s a simple token currency they can just mint and burn supply. The subID registration fees go to the rootID.``3`` is for Ethereum ERC-20 mapped tokens. [Read more](/currencies/mapping-1:1-eth)
What does the "options" parameter in Verus currency definition do?

The "options" parameter in Verus currency definition is used to specify various properties of the currency. It is a bitfield, which means that individual options can be combined by adding their values. For example, "options":33 would launch a basket currency, which is a combination of options 1 and 32.

| Options # | Details | | -: |:-----| | 1 | The currency has reserves, and can be converted to and from the reserves (option 32 needs to be added). Can have one currency as its reserves, or multiple with up to 10 currencies. This is a “Basket currency” — a currency with a basket of reserves. Such a currency can be launched centralized or decentralized. | | 2 | Only the controlling VerusID (the namespace of the currency, the rootID) can create subIDs. | | 8 | Referrals and discounts are enabled for subID creation. | | 16 | Referrals are required for subID creation. | | 32 | The currency is a simple token currency without any reserves. Such a currency can be launched centralized or decentralized. This option is also used for [Ethereum ERC-20 mapped tokens](/currencies/mapping-1:1-eth). | | 2048 | A single satoshi (0.00000001) NFT token is created & has tokenized control of the root VerusID. Which means you can send the single satoshi token to other addresses and then they have control of the root VerusID. |Let’s give some examples of combined options: - ``"options":33`` — this launches a basket currency. It is options 1 + 32 combined. - ``"options":2080`` — this launches a single satoshi token that has control of the root VerusID. It is options 32 + 2048 combined. - ``"options":35`` — this launches a basket currency, and only the rootID can create subIDs. It is options 1 + 2 + 32 combined.## Defining parameters Next up are the parameters. Choose the parameters wisely to launch a currency that suits any need. Not all parameters are needed or combinable. There are many to go through, so let’s start.### **"proofprotocol"** This parameter defines, among others, if the currency is centralized or decentralized. You can choose 1,2 or 3.``1`` is default, which launches a decentralized currency (no need to include this parameter when defining such a currency). When subIDs are created with this option, the registration fees are burned.``2`` is for a centralized currency. If it’s a basket currency the rootID can mint and burn supply while automatically lowering and raising the reserve ratio (also anyone can burn supply without lowering the reserve ratio). Or when it’s a simple token currency they can just mint and burn supply. The subID registration fees go to the rootID.``3`` is for Ethereum ERC-20 mapped tokens.
